Comment:
Hi everyone!

GM Cyrano (Afro) asked me to annotate this game and another against his opponent, Akjoltoy who needs just one rating point to get to 2700 - wow!  I will give the commentary and hopefully somebody can provide a little deeper analysis, so here goes.   Afro opens with 1. e4 and his opponent responds with e6 which is the French Defense.
3. d4 - pretty standard follow up.
3. d4 - pretty standard follow up.
4. e5.  This pawn advance is often played by white in the French Defense to exert a cramp on black's game.  However, black does find some ingenious ways of getting round the cramp!
4. e5.  This pawn advance is often played by white in the French Defense to exert a cramp on black's game.  However, black does find some ingenious ways of getting round the cramp!

6. bxc3 - B for N trade which busts up white's queenside pawns.
6. bxc3 - B for N trade which busts up white's queenside pawns.
6. bxc3 - B for N trade which busts up white's queenside pawns.
6. bxc3 - B for N trade which busts up white's queenside pawns.
6. .... Ne7 - this is the way black usually develops the knight.  It then sometimes goes to g6.
7. Qg4 - with a black bishop not defending g7 white usually attacks it with his queen to try and provoke a weakness in black's castled position by an impromptu g6.
9. Qxh7 - black has neither played g6 or castled and allowed the WQ to inflict mayhem on his position.  It will be interesting to see what counterplay black has to this.

10. Ne2 - Afro develops his knight to this square to prevent a nasty queen check on c3.

11. .... dxc3 - recovers pawn loss and puts a crimp on Afro's queenside.
